senses.de: To have something in your hand or arms
senses.ex: Please hold these apples for me.

Tips.title: Temporary Action
Tips.description: Use 'hold' to describe a brief action, where objects are not kept for long.
Tips.example: Can you hold my coat while I tie my shoes?

Tips.title: Support Needed
Tips.description: 'Hold' suggests something might fall or requires support without grip.
Tips.example: Hold the ladder steady for me, please.

senses.de: To keep something in a particular state or position
senses.ex: Hold the door open for her.

Tips.title: Stasis Implication
Tips.description: 'Hold' in this sense means to maintain position without movement.
Tips.example: Hold your smile a little longer for the camera!

Tips.title: Resistance
Tips.description: 'Hold' conveys opposing forces, like wind, pressure, or competition.
Tips.example: The ship held its course despite the storm.

senses.de: To contain or to be able to contain something
senses.ex: This bucket can hold two gallons of water.

Tips.title: Volume Measure
Tips.description: 'Hold' can indicate an item's capacity. Important for recipes or storage.
Tips.example: This jar holds exactly one liter.

Tips.title: Not Always Liquid
Tips.description: Though often used for fluids, 'hold' can refer to any substance.
Tips.example: This box can hold all my books.

senses.de: To organize and participate in a meeting or event
senses.ex: We are planning to hold a meeting next week.

Tips.title: Formal Events
Tips.description: Use 'hold' for scheduled, official, or formal gatherings.
Tips.example: The university will hold its graduation ceremony in June.

Tips.title: Pre-Planning
Tips.description: 'Hold' implies an event was organized in advance, not spontaneous.
Tips.example: They decided to hold a banquet to celebrate the achievement.

senses.ex: I hold the opinion that exercise is important for good health.

Tips.title: Personal Conviction
Tips.description: 'Hold' can reflect a firmly believed personal viewpoint or principle.
Tips.example: She holds strong views on environmental protection.

Tips.title: Debate and Discussion
Tips.description: This use of 'hold' often appears in contexts of intellectual debate.
Tips.example: In the debate, he held that taxes should be lowered.

senses.de: To bind by a legal or moral tie
senses.ex: I am held by my promise.

Tips.title: Commitment
Tips.description: Shows a moral or legal obligation someone is bound to honor.
Tips.example: The company is held to high ethical standards.

Tips.title: Accountability Emphasis
Tips.description: 'Hold' emphasizes the importance of keeping one's word or promise.
Tips.example: Leaders are held accountable for their decisions.

senses.ex: I had to hold my anger in check.

Tips.title: Emotional Restraint
Tips.description: Use 'hold' to describe controlling emotions or actions voluntarily.
Tips.example: Even though he was upset, he held his composure.

Tips.title: Preventing Action
Tips.description: Sometimes 'hold' means to stop someone or something from a reaction.
Tips.example: He was so funny, I could hardly hold my laughter.

senses.de: An act or manner of grasping something
senses.ex: He has a strong hold on the rope.

Tips.title: Physical Control
Tips.description: 'Hold' as a noun means the act of grabbing something effectively.
Tips.example: With a firm hold of the leash, she walked the big dog.

Tips.title: Safety Implication
Tips.description: A 'hold' often implies safety, as in preventing someone from falling.
Tips.example: Grab hold of the railing while walking down the icy stairs.

Carry.wordDefinition:
Carry and hold are both verbs that describe actions related to moving an object from one place to another, but they have different nuances of meaning.

To carry something means to support the weight of an object and move it while holding it in your hands or arms. Carrying usually implies that you are transporting something from one place to another, such as carrying groceries from the store to your car.

Carry is used when you need to move an object from one place to another while holding it, while hold is used when you need to grip and keep something steady in one place.

Clasp.wordDefinition:
Clasp and hold both refer to ways of grasping or gripping something, but there are subtle differences in how each word is used.

A clasp typically refers to a fastener or closure that is used to hold something together, such as a snap or a buckle. To clasp something means to secure it with a closure or fastener.

For example, you might clasp a necklace around your neck by fastening its clasp.

A clasp is a specific type of securing mechanism, while holding is a general term for grasping or gripping something.

Clench.wordDefinition:
Clench means to tightly grip or squeeze something, usually with one's hands, teeth, or fists. It implies a forceful and intense action.

For example, if you are angry, you might clench your fists.

Clutch.wordDefinition:
Clutch means to grab onto something tightly and securely, often in a moment of urgency or need.

For example, a basketball player might clutch the ball tightly before taking a shot.

It can be used in a wider range of contexts than 'clutch.' For example, a person might hold a book while reading, or hold a door open for someone else.

Clutch implies a stronger, more urgent grip than hold, and is often used in situations where there is some imminent or pressing danger.

Embrace.wordDefinition:
Embrace usually refers to a physical or emotional hug, accepting something or someone, or adopting a new idea or belief.

For instance, you can embrace a loved one or embrace a new challenge.

Embrace has emotional or intellectual connotation, while hold is more physical.

Grasp.wordDefinition:
Grasp means to hold something tightly and firmly, usually with the fingers. For example, you might grasp a basketball tightly while dribbling down the court.

Grasp suggests a strong and intentional hold, while hold is a more generic term for physically keeping something in place.

Grip.wordDefinition:
Grip and hold both refer to the act of grasping or holding onto something, but they are used in different contexts.

Grip usually describes how we hold onto something tightly, with force or pressure.

It is often used in sports like weightlifting, where you need a strong grip to lift heavy weights. You might also use the word grip when talking about holding onto something like a handle, where you need to make sure you have a firm grasp and won't drop it.

Grip refers to holding onto something tightly with force or pressure, usually in situations where strength is needed.

Keep.wordDefinition:
Both hold and keep essentially mean to have or possess something.

However, hold typically refers to physically grasping or containing something in your hand, while keep generally implies ownership or control over something for a period of time.

For example, you might hold a book while reading it, and then keep it on your bookshelf when you're done. Or you could hold a friend's phone for them while they tie their shoe, but you wouldn't keep it because it's not yours.

The difference between hold and keep often comes down to the context and the specific circumstances involved.

Retain.wordDefinition:
The words hold and retain have similar meanings, but there is a slight difference in their usage.

Retain means to keep something in one's possession or to remember something.

It is often used in a more abstract sense. For example, you could say "The lawyer will retain the document for reference" or "I struggle to retain information from my history class".

Hold is more often used when talking about physically holding onto something, while retain is used when talking about keeping or remembering something more abstract.

Support.wordDefinition:
Support means to hold up or help something. For example, you can support a friend by helping them through a tough time.

Hold means to keep something from falling or moving, while support means to help hold something up or provide assistance to someone or something.
